S1.T1.caption: Table 1: Comparison of the order of the necessary number of communication rounds to satisfy 𝔼​‖f​(xout)‖2≤ε𝔼superscriptnorm𝑓subscript𝑥out2𝜀\mathbb{E}\|f(x_{\mathrm{out}})\|^{2}\leq\varepsilon (or f​(xout)−f​(x∗)≤ε𝑓subscript𝑥out𝑓subscript𝑥𝜀f(x_{\mathrm{out}})-f(x_{*})\leq\varepsilon for convex f𝑓f). "Extra Assumptions” indicates the necessary assumptions to derive the results other than Assumptions 2, 3 and 4 in Section 2. ε𝜀\varepsilon is the desired optimization accuracy. ℬℬ\mathcal{B} is the local computation budget that is the allowed number of single stochastic gradient computations per communication round for each worker. P𝑃P is the number of workers. n𝑛n is the total number of samples and is possibly ∞\infty in online (i.e., expected risk minimization) settings. The smoothness of local objectives L𝐿L, the variance of a single stochastic gradient σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} and gradient boundedness G𝐺G are regarded as Θ​(1)Θ1\Theta(1) for ease of presentation. Note that in this notation, second-order heterogeneity ζ𝜁\zeta always satisfies ζ≤Θ​(L)=Θ​(1)𝜁Θ𝐿Θ1\zeta\leq\Theta(L)=\Theta(1). σdif2superscriptsubscript𝜎dif2\sigma_{\mathrm{dif}}^{2} is the squared local gradient norm at an optimum (for the precise definition, see (Khaled et al., 2020)).

references: Theoretical Features. We analyse BVR-L-SGD for general nonconvex smooth objectives under second-order heterogeneity assumption, which interpolates the heterogeneity of local objectives between the identical case and the extremely non-IID case, and plays a critical role in our nonconvex analysis. The comparison of the communication complexities of our method with the most relevant existing results is given in Table 1. The communication complexity of BVR-L-SGD has a better dependence on εε\varepsilon than minibatch SGD, local SGD and SCAFFOLD. When ℬ​P≫n∧1/εmuch-greater-thanℬ𝑃𝑛1𝜀\mathcal{B}P\gg\sqrt{n\wedge 1/\varepsilon} and the second-order heterogeneity ζ𝜁\zeta of local objectives is small relative to the smoothness L𝐿L, BVR-L-SGD strictly surpasses minibatch SARAH. Furthermore, BVR-L-SGD is the first method that breaks the barrier of communication complexity 1/ε1ε1/\varepsilon when local computation budget ℬ→∞→ℬ\mathcal{B}\to\infty, for general smooth nonconvex objectives with small heterogeneity ζ𝜁\zeta. Importantly, even when the heterogeneity is high, the communication complexity of our method is never worse than the ones of the existing methods since the second-order heterogeneity ζ𝜁\zeta is bounded by two times the smoothness L𝐿L of local objectives444For the details, see Assumption 1 in Section 2.

Results 1: Effect of the heterogeneity.  Here, we investigate the effect of the heterogeneity on the convergence speed of the algorithms. To clarify the pure effect of the heterogeneity, we fixed the local computation budget ℬℬ\mathcal{B} to 1,02410241,024, which was the largest one in our experiments. Figure 2 shows the comparison of the best-achieved train loss and test accuracy in 3,00030003,000 communication rounds against heterogeneity parameter q𝑞q. From this, we can see that the convergence speed of the local methods deteriorated as heterogeneity parameter q𝑞q increased. Particularly, the degree of the performance degradation of L-SGD and SCAFFOLD was serious. In contrast, this phenomenon was not observed for non-local methods, because the convergence rates of non-local methods do not depend on heterogeneity ζ𝜁\zeta as in Table 1. Importantly, even for the largest q𝑞q, BVR-L-SGD significantly outperformed the other methods.

Results 2: Effect of the local computation budget size.  Now, we examine the effect of the size of the local computation budget ℬℬ\mathcal{B} to the convergence speed. For this purpose, we fixed heterogeneity parameter q𝑞q to the smallest one. Figure 3 shows the comparison of the best-achieved train loss and test accuracy against local computation budget ℬℬ\mathcal{B}. We can see that the local methods improved their performances as local computation budget ℬℬ\mathcal{B} increased, but non-local methods did not. This is because local methods can potentially achieve a smaller communication complexity than 1/ε1𝜀1/\varepsilon by increasing ℬℬ\mathcal{B} for small ζ𝜁\zeta, but non-local methods can not break the barrier of 1/ε1𝜀1/\varepsilon for any ℬℬ\mathcal{B} as in Table 1.
